Denying Contingency
2. Denying Contingency

Philosophers have responded to this problem in several different ways.
One obvious way to respond is simply to claim that there are no future
contingent events, despite appearances to the contrary. Different
people have taken this approach for different reasons. Some are
attracted to the idea that every event has a prior sufficient cause
(see the entry on
 causal determinism).
 Others believe that the idea of free choice does not require anything
like real contingency or the possibility of doing or intending
otherwise (see the entries on
 compatibilism
 and
 free will).
 Still others believe that God’s providential control over the
world is so thorough and detailed that nothing is left to chance, not
even the apparently free choices of human beings (see Calvin 1536,
Carson 1981, Feinberg 1986, Furlong 2019, and White 2019, along with
the entry on
 divine providence).
 So one possible response to the difficulty here is to give up one
half of the problem by denying that there are any future contingent
events in the first place. To return to our example from the Christian
tradition, when Jesus truly prophecies that Peter will deny him three
times before the cock crows, there is no philosophical puzzle as long
as we do not claim that Peter’s denials are contingent
events.

Many philosophers and theologians do not find this approach very
promising, though, because they believe strongly in future contingent
events, especially human free choices. How else might one respond to
the problem posed by prophecies concerning future contingent
events?
